Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(2) Summary

Digital Transformation frequently results in transitioning to API-oriented IT strategies. API-centric ecosystems have to balance two complementary goals: Giving API development teams the autonomy and flexibility to develop products as effectively as possible, and making sure that the growing and constantly evolving landscape of APIs has a level of design quality and coherence that allows API consumers to utilize this landscape effectively. This can be a challenge for IT architecture, in particular when transitioning from a more traditional view of architecture, where the main perspective was that of architecture as a top-down process that starts with modeling a system, and ends with delivering a running system. In loosely coupled API-centric systems, architecture at the ecosystem level takes a distinctively different approach: It observes the creation and evolution of components and uses these observations to evolve the constraints of the ecosystem, and to provide support and tooling where necessary. Continuous Architecting is the process that supports the balance between component goals and ecosystem goals: It collects feedback from the ecosystem in the form of observations from developers and users and the organization, and translates those into ways that improve and support component development.

(8) Digital Transformation is Everywhere



Digital Transformation Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(9) Digital Transformation: Business & Technology Align



Digital Transformation Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(10) Digital Transformation is Continuous

  • Digital transformation happens at two different levels
    • Transforming the organization to become better at adapting to changes
    • Identifying and implementing capabilities that improve the organization
  • You're never done with digital transformation
    • Business must be empowered and capable to identify opportunities
    • Organization must be capable of acting fast to capture opportunities
    • Technology must be able to realize opportunities quickly and safely


Digital Transformation Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(11) Dimensions of API Management Continuity

  • Product Development Continuity → Microservices and DevOps
  • Product Evolution Continuity → Microservices and Product Lifecycle
  • Landscape Continuity → Managing the evolving API landscape
  • Scope Continuity → External/internal as contextual difference
  • Architectural Continuity → Continuous observation and adaptation of API architecture

(13) Interface Design



Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(14) Interface Continuity and Evolution



Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(15) API your APIs

  • Expose design-time and runtime API information in the API
    • Design-time allows automation of API landscape overview
    • Runtime allows automation of API landscape status
  • Follow robust extensibility principles [http://dret.typepad.com/dretblog/2016/04/robust-extensibility.html] for these API APIs
    • Meaningful Core: Start with a simple but useful scenario
    • Extension Points: Think about how scenarios might evolve
    • Processing Model: Be clear about how extensions are handled


Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(16) Emerging API Patterns

  • Self-description for APIs is increasing
  • Problem details [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/RFC/7807] as a way how APIs expose error information
    • Enables generic error handling but also allows additional information
  • Home documents [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/nottingham-json-home] as a way how APIs provide starting pages
    • Enables harvesting of API start points but also allows additional information
  • Healthcheck reports [http://webconcepts.info/specs/IETF/I-D/inadarei-api-health-check] as a way how APIs expose status information
    • Enables landscape-level status reports but also allows additional information


Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(17) The Essence of Continuous Architecting

  • Architecture is informed by solutions
  • Architecture's job is to support solutions
  • Architecture's job is to optimize the solution landscape
  • Architecture focuses on solution interfaces


Product Management

Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(19) Product Pillars and Maturity

  • API Products are created in the context of (possibly implicit) API landscapes
    • They are influenced by the culture and constraints of the landscape
  • Product Pillars identify areas of investment during an API's lifetime
  • Product Maturity describes stages of an API product's lifetime


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(20) CAM Product Compass



Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(21) CAM Product Compass: Maturity



Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(22) CAM Product Compass: Change Management

  • Example question: If your design includes a plan for evolving the API itself, do you document this clearly so that clients know what to expect?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(23) CAM Product Compass: Deployment

  • Example question: Deployment is aligned with the change management principles, so that if necessary, multiple versions can be operated and potentially discovered in parallel.


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(24) CAM Product Compass: Design

  • Example question: Given the API's style and technology, is it using a recommended and/or standardized description format that makes it easier for consumers to gain an initial understanding of the API, possibly aided by tooling they can use?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(25) CAM Product Compass: Development

  • Example question: Does development include technologies and/or tools that are not part of the recommended development technologies and/or tools in the organization?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(26) CAM Product Compass: Discovery

  • Example question: Based on the change management strategy, it is made sure that it is always the most recent version that is made available through all discovery channels.


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(27) CAM Product Compass: Documentation

  • Example question: Is the documentation and learning experience for the API based on the strategic goals of the API product?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(28) CAM Product Compass: Monitoring

  • Example question: Is all the monitoring information collected in a way that it can be easily accessed and reused?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(29) CAM Product Compass: Security

  • Example question: Documentation and design expose as little information about implementation details as possible to reduce the attack surface.


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(30) CAM Product Compass: Strategy

  • Example question: Do you have a clearly defined and documented reason why the API exists?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(31) CAM Product Compass: Testing

  • Example question: Do your tests include scenarios where consumed APIs are not performing or are not reachable, in order to test for resiliency of the API product?


Product Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

API Landscape Management

Outline (API Landscape Management)

  2. Digital Transformation [4]

  5. API Landscape Management [11]
  6. Conclusions [2]
API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(34) Increasing Product Team Productivity

  • API product teams need guidance, autonomy, and support
    • Guidance helps understanding and navigating the current landscape
    • Autonomy allows choices to be made driven by product and user needs
    • Support increases productivity of teams for cross-cutting concerns
  • Balancing product value and product portfolio value
    • Products focus on achieving local maxima for product value
    • Landscapes focus on achieving global maxima across all products


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(35) CAM Landscape Compass



API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(36) V1: Variety

  • APIs come in many different shapes (on different levels)
    • API style moved from RPC (SOAP) to Web APIs
    • Web API style starts embracing query-style APIs (GraphQL)
  • Allow more than one way to address a problem
    • Embrace diversity as a way to explore new ways to solve a problem
Example Question: How easy is it for your landscape to embrace and support a new API technology?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(37) V2: Vocabulary

  • APIs are languages that define how two parties communicate
  • Each API is a mix of reused technology and problem-specific definitions
    • Reusing generic metamodels such as XML or JSON is a natural choice for most
    • Reusing specific models is a harder design task
  • Maximizing reuse benefits producers and consumers
    • Producers don't have to re-invent the wheel for solved problems
    • Consumers can understand part of the API because they know it already
Example Question: Is there an easy way for developers to discover the vocabularies that are in use throughout existing APIs?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(38) V3: Volume

  • API volume is a good thing and should be encouraged
    • More components in an ecosystem mean more choice and better selection
    • Selection should be within the ecosystem, not getting into the ecosystem
  • Guidelines and support needs to grow and evolve along ecosystem growth
    • Identifying bottlenecks for the product teams helps to make teams more productive
    • Identifying bottlenecks for the ecosystem helps to eliminate participation barriers
Example Question: How easy is it for developers to design, implement, and deploy a new product?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(39) V4: Velocity

  • Change frequency is a good thing and should be encouraged
  • Changes in consumption ideally are invisible to producers
    • Onboarding is invisible to producers
    • Scalability should be built into each product
  • Changes in products ideally are invisible to consumers
    1. Change management [V7: Versioning (1)] provides a robust product evolution path
    2. Product evolution is opaque and consumers always use their favorite version
Example Question: Does anything in the API landscape slow down teams when creating or changing APIs?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(40) V5: Vulnerability

  • Every API is a possible attack vector into a capability
  • Security is easy to get wrong and hard to get right
  • Security often gets API programs started
  • Identity can become an important asset for large organizations
    • GDPR is hard to get right without solid identity management
Example Question: Are APIs designed from the ground up to be potentially externalizable?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(41) V6: Visibility

  • Product catalogs are essential for product success
  • Visibility refinement depends on the expected target audience
    • Private APIs may be able to get away with just making them findable
    • Partner APIs already need some marketing so that partners will notice
    • Public APIs may need a comprehensive plan for a competitive market presence
Example Question: How easy it is for architects, teams, and consumers to explore the entire API landscape?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(42) V7: Versioning

  • API success creates potential problem for API products
    • More usage means more feedback means more input and motivation to improve the product
    • More usage means greater risk for potential disruption of existing consumers
  • Managing products and their implementations
    • Implementations should use well-know schemes such as Semantic Versioning [http://semver.org/]
    • APIs should expose a subset of the implementation version information
    • API management can take care of some product management issues
Example Question: Are APIs designed and implemented so that changes create as little disruption as possible?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(43) V8: Volatility

  • Products in ecosystems appear, change, and disappear
    • Change is not a problem but a feature that is essential for ecosystem growth
  • Treating dependencies responsibly increases product resilience
    • Not making any assumptions about APIs always being accessible
    • Always behaving well when APIs are inaccessible
  • Client-side products (such as SDKs) need to be resilient
  • Testing always should include degraded and inaccessible API dependencies
Example Question: Are all dependencies implemented to be visible and to behave responsibly when some APIs fail?


API Landscape Management Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(44) Guidelines: Why? What? How? Test!

  • Guidance needs to be motivated, clear, actionable, and testable
    • Why explains why a problem is a problem
    • What explains a design to address the problem
    • How explains how to implement the solution
    • Test provides feedback to verify compliance
  • Guidance is further qualified by when it is applicable
    • Guidance evolution has stages such as experimental/production/deprecated
    • Guidance applicability is decided by API maturity stage
  • Governance is about how the guidelines are enforced/encouraged


Conclusions

Outline (Conclusions)

Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems

(46) Guiding Evolutionary Architecture

  • Create rules what to do and not how to do it
  • When you say what to do also explain why this constraint exists
  • Propose/suggest/support at least one way how to satisfy the constraint
  • Be open to new ways of how constraints can be satisfied
  • Explain how to verify compliance with the constraint


Conclusions Erik Wilde (@dret): Continuous Architecting: Architecture for Loosely Coupled Systems
